facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 577 of 1961 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 577 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Allahabad High Court judgment and decree dated January 7, 1959 in Second Appeal No. 448 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated January 7, 1959, of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 448 of 1952.

facts.text: Nine persons, including Kedar Nath, instituted suit for ejectment and recovery of rent against two defendants.

anchor.surface_text: Nine persons, including Kedar Nath, instituted a suit for ejectment and recovery of rent against two defendants on the allegation that defendant No. I was the tenant-inchief who had sub-let the premises to defendant No. 2.

facts.text: Defendant No. 1 was the tenant-in-chief who sub-let the premises to defendant No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that defendant No. I was the tenant-inchief who had sub-let the premises to defendant No. 2.

facts.text: Suit for ejectment decreed against both defendants and for arrears of rent against defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The suit for ejectment was decreed against both the defendants and for arrears of rent against defendant No. 1.

facts.text: On appeal by defendant No. 2, District Judge set aside decree for ejectment against defendant No. 2 and confirmed rest against defendant No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by defendant No. 2 the District judge set aside the decree for ejectment against defendant No. 2 and companyfirmed the rest of the decree against defendant No. 1.

facts.text: Nine original plaintiffs filed second appeal in High Court on February 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decree that the nine original plaintiffs filed the second appeal in the High Court on February 29, 1952.

facts.text: Kedar Nath, appellant No. 3, died on September 8, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Kedar Nath, appellant No. 3, died on September 8, 1955.

facts.text: Appeal abated as to Kedar Nath due to no application for legal representatives within time per O. XXII rr. 3 and 11 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: In view of rr. 3 and 11 of O. XXII of the Code of Civil Procedure, hereinafter called the Code, the appeal abated so far as Kedar Nath was companycerned as numberapplication for bringing his legal representatives on the record was made within the prescribed time.

facts.text: On October 1, 1956, applications filed in High Court: one under s.5 Limitation Act for condonation of delay, other for substitution of Bithal Das and Banarsi Das, sons of Kedar Nath.

anchor.surface_text: On October 1, 1956, two applications were filed in the High Court One was an application under s. 5 of the Limitation Act for the companydonation of the delay in filing the application for substitution of the heirs in placec of Kedar Nath. The other was the application for substitution in which it was prayed that Bithal Das and Banarsi Das, the sons of Kedar Nath, deceased, be substituted in place of the deceased appellant as they were his heirs and representatives.

facts.text: Two applications dismissed on May 1, 1957, appeal abated against Kedar Nath.

anchor.surface_text: These two applications were dismissed on May 1, 1957, with the result that the appeal stood abated as against Kedar Nath.

facts.text: Bhagwati Prasad, appellant No. 9, died on July 2, 1956; widow Remeshwari Devi brought on record.

anchor.surface_text: Bhagwati Prasad, appellant No. 9 also died on July 2,1956. His widow, Remeshwari Devi, was brought on the record in his place.

facts.text: On September 1, 1958, at hearing, respondent raised preliminary objection that entire appeal abated.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeals of the appellants other than Kedar Nath came up for hearing on September 1, 1958, a preliminary objection was taken for the, respondent that the entire appeal had abated.

facts.text: Appellants contended deceased belonged to joint Hindu family, other members on record, no need for substitution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. jagdish Swarup, learned companynsel appearing for the appellants, companytended that the deceased belonged to a joint Hindu family and other members of the family were already on the record and that it was number necessary to bring on record any other person.

facts.text: On September 8, 1958, affidavit filed by Suraj Prasad Misra stating Lala Ram Chandra Prasad managed family properties including disputed one.

anchor.surface_text: On September 8, 1958, an affidavit was filed by Suraj Prasad Misra pairokar of the appellants. Para 9 of the Affidavit stated that Lala Ram Chandra Prasad, appellant No. 8, managed the family properties including the one in dispute which was joint and looked after the affairs of the properties and acted for and on behalf of the family and was already on the record.

facts.text: Counter-affidavit filed stating family not joint, members separated, separate income-tax, property not joint.

anchor.surface_text: A companynter-affidavit was filed stating that the allegations in para 9 of the affidavit were misleading, that there was numberallegation in the affidavit that the family was a joint Hindu family and that the true facts were that the family of the plaintiffsappellants was number a joint family, that the members were separated, that Lala Ram Chandra Prasad was number karta of the joint Hindu family, that the plaintiffs were assessed to income-tax separately and that the property in dispute was number joint- family property or even joint property.

facts.text: Rejoinder affidavit by Sri Narain re-affirming Ram Chandra Prasad managed house property for family.

anchor.surface_text: A rejoinder affidavit was then filed by Sri Narain, general agent of the appellants stating that the aforesaid statements in the companynteraffidavit were misleading and irrelevant and re- affirming that Ram Chandra Prasad managed the house property of the family including the one in dispute and that he looked after the affairs of the house property and acted for and on behalf of the family just as other members of the family looked after other affairs including the business belonging to the family.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed second appeal on ground that appeal abated entirely due to Baij Nath case.

anchor.surface_text: It accordingly dismissed the appeal. It is against this decree -that this appeal has been filed after obtaining special leave.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on May 3, 1963 by RAGHBAR DAYAL J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. May 3 The judgement of the Court was delivered by RAGHBAR DAYAL J.-

facts.text: Court held appellants did not prove they constituted joint Hindu family with Kedar Nath.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the companytents of the various affidavits filed by the parties subsequent to the point being raised that Kedar Nath, the deceased appellant and the surviving appellants companystituted a joint Hindu family. They clearly indicate that the affidavits filed on behalf of the appellants made numberaverment that Kedar Nath and the surviving appellants formed a joint Hindu family, even though time had been given to them for filing an affidavit stating such a fact.

facts.text: Application for substitution treated Kedar Nath as not member of joint family.

anchor.surface_text: It is further of significance that the application made on October 1, 1956, for substituting the sons of Kedar Nath in his place stated that they were his heirs and legal representatives. The application was on the basis that Kedar Nath was number a member of the joint Hindu family.

facts.text: Court rejected contention that O. XLI r.4 allows surviving appellants to continue appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We do number agree with this companytention Rule 4 of O.XLI reads Where there are more plaintiffs or more defendants than one in a suit, and the decree appealed from proceeds on any ground companymon to all the plaintiffs or to all the defendants, any one of the plaintiffs or of the defendants may appeal from the whole decree,

facts.text: Second appeal was filed by all plaintiffs jointly, not by some under O.XLI r.4.

anchor.surface_text: The second appeal filed in the High Court was number filed by any one or by even some of the plaintiffs as an appeal against the whole decree, but was filed by all the plaintiffs jointly, and, therefore, was number an appeal to which the provisions of r. 4 O.XLI companyld apply.

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court filed after special leave.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this decree -that this appeal has been filed after obtaining special leave.

anchor.surface_text: This rule reads The Appellate Court shall have power to pass any decree and make any order which ought to have been passed or made and to pass or make such further or other decree or order as the case may require, and this power may be exercised by the Court notwithstanding that the appeal is as to part only of the decree and may be exercised in favour of all or any of the respondents or parties, although such respondents or parties may not have filed any appeal or objection Provided that the Appellate Court shall not make any order under section 35A,

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Order XXII Rule 2 CPC apply instead of Rule 3, as the nine appellants constituted a joint Hindu family such that the surviving plaintiffs could continue the appeal without substitution of the deceased's legal representatives?

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Sarjoo Prasad, learned counsel for the appellants, has raised two points. One is that the provision of r. 2 of XXII and not of r. 3 of that Order apply to the facts of this case as the nine appellants constitute a joint Hindu family and the surviving plaintiffs could continue the appeal.

issues.text: Whether, even if the appeal abated under Order XXII Rule 3 as to the deceased appellant Kedar Nath, the surviving appellants could continue the appeal and seek reversal of the whole decree under Order XLI Rule 4 CPC?

anchor.surface_text: The second point is that if the provisions of r. 3 of O.XXII applied and the appeal of Kedar Nath had abated, the provisions of r. 4 of O.XLI have not been correctly construed in Baij Nath v. Ram Bharose and Ramphal Sahu Babu Satdeo Jha.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of Order XLI Rule 4 CPC override the provisions of Order XXII Rule 9 CPC in cases of abatement during pendency of appeal?

anchor.surface_text: No question of the Provisions of r. 4 of O.XLI overriding the provisions of r. 9 of O. XXII arises. The two deal with different stages of the appeal and provide for different contingencies.

issues.text: Whether Order XLI Rule 33 CPC empowers the appellate court to pass a decree in favour of the rights and interests of the deceased appellant Kedar Nath despite abatement of his appeal?

anchor.surface_text: OrderXLI, r. 33 is of no greater help to the contention of the appellants that their appeal could continue even though the appeal by Kedar Nath had abated, as the Court could have passed a decree in favour of the rights and interests of Kedar Nath, deceased, as well.

XXII of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavits lacked direct averment of joint family despite opportunity; substitution application treated sons as individual heirs inconsistent with joint status; separate income-tax assessments.

holdings.text: We do not agree with this contention... The second appeal filed in the High Court was not filed by any one or by even some of the plaintiffs as an appeal against the whole decree, but was filed by all the plaintiffs jointly, and, therefore, was not an appeal to which the provisions of r. 4 O.XLI could apply.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree with this contention Rule 4 of O.XLI reads Where there are more plaintiffs or more defendants than one in a suit, and the decree appealed from proceeds on any ground common to all the plaintiffs or to all the defendants, any one of the plaintiffs or of the defendants may appeal from the whole decree,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 4 enables one or some to file against whole decree on common ground, but here all filed jointly; cannot retroactively treat as r.4 appeal post-abatement as time-barred and inconsistent with representation principle.

holdings.text: Kedar Nath's appeal has abated and the decree in favour of the respondents has become final against his legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: Kedar Naths appeal has abated and the decree in favour of the respondents has become final against his legal representatives. His legal representatives cannot eject the defendants from the premises in suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abatement finalizes decree as to deceased; appellate court cannot modify directly or indirectly, per State of Punjab v. Nathu Ram.

holdings.text: No question of the Provisions of r. 4 of O.XLI overriding the provisions of r. 9 of O. XXII arises. The two deal with different stages of the appeal and provide for different contingencies.

anchor.surface_text: No question of the Provisions of r. 4 of O.XLI overriding the provisions of r. 9 of O. XXII arises. The two deal with different stages of the appeal and provide for different contingencies. Rule 4 of 0 XLI applies to the stage when an appeal is filed

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.4 at filing stage for one/some appealing whole; r.9 during pendency on death/abatement; harmonious construction, no conflict.

holdings.text: Order XLI, r. 33 is of no greater help to the contention of the appellants that their appeal could continue even though the appeal by Kedar Nath had abated, as the Court could have passed a decree in favour of the rights and interests of Kedar Nath, deceased, as well.

anchor.surface_text: OrderXLI, r. 33 is of no greater help to the contention of the appellants that their appeal could continue even though the appeal by Kedar Nath had abated, as the Court could have passed a decree in favour of the rights and interests of Kedar Nath, deceased, as well.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.33 empowers decrees as case requires but not to nullify abatement or create contradictory decrees; applies to competent appeals only, per Mahomed Khaleel Shirazi; discretionary power not for negligent parties.

holdings.text: We are, therefore, of opinion that the High Court could not have heard the appeal of the surviving appellants when the appeal by kedar Nath had abated as all the appellants had a common right and interest in getting a decree of ejectment against defendant No. 2.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint indivisible interests mean abatement as to one abates entire appeal to avoid inconsistent decrees; affirms High Court dismissal; majority High Courts correct.

holdings.text: Suffice it to say that the majority of the High Courts have taken the correct view viz., that the appellate Court has no power to proceed with the appeal and to reverse and vary the decree in favour of all the plaintiffs or defendants under O. XLI, r. 4.

precedents.citation: State of Punjab v. Nathu Ram 1

anchor.surface_text: State of Punjab v. Nathu Ram 1 . The abatement of an appeal means number only that the decree between the appellant and the deceased respondent had become final, but also, as a necessary companyollary, that the appellate Court cannot, in any way, modify that decree directly or indirectly.

precedents.case_name: State of Punjab v. Nathu Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: abatement means decree becomes final and appellate court cannot modify it directly or indirectly
precedents.cited_holding: The abatement of an appeal means not only that the decree between the appellant and the deceased respondent had become final, but also, as a necessary corollary, that the appellate Court cannot, in any way, modify that decree directly or indirectly.

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree with this contention Rule 4 of O.XLI reads Where there are more plaintiffs or more defendants than one in a suit, and the decree appealed from proceeds on any ground common to all the plaintiffs or to all the defendants, any one of the plaintiffs or of the defendants may appeal from the whole decree,

We are, therefore, of opinion that the High Court companyld number have heard the appeal of the surviving appellants when the appeal by kedar Nath had abated as all the appellants had a companymon right and interest in getting a decree of ejectment against defendant No. 2 and such decree companyld have been on a ground companymon to all of them. The defendant cannot be ejected from the premises when he has a right to remain in occupation of the premises on the basis of the decree holding that Kedar Nath, one of the persons having a joint interest in letting out the property companyld number have ejected him.
